Let us recall their results for the case of CAC with prime lengths. Put

\mathcal { O } ( p ) = \left\{ \begin{array} { c l } { \frac { p - 1 } { 2 o _ { p } ( 2 ) } } & { \mathrm { i f } o _ { p } ( 2 ) \mathrm { i s } \mathrm { o d d } , } \\ { \frac { p - 1 } { o _ { p } ( 2 ) } } & { \mathrm { i f } o _ { p } ( 2 ) \equiv 2 \pmod { 4 } , } \\ { 0 } & { \mathrm { i f } 4 \mid o _ { p } ( 2 ) } \end{array} \right.
to be the size of optimal CAC of length
\frac { p - 1 - 2 \mathcal { O } ( p ) } { 4 } \leq M ( p ) \leq \frac { p - 1 - 2 \mathcal { O } ( p ) } { 4 } + \left\lfloor \frac { \mathcal { O } ( p ) } { 3 } \right\rfloor .
Note that in the case where O(p)â‰¤2,inequality  already gives that M(p)= p-1-26(p).
the authors provide an algorithm for constructing nonequi-difference CAC
and conjectured that the algorithm produces a CAC consists of D-1-26(p)
nonequi-difference codewords. In other words,the upper bound
can be attained and hence the CAC obtained by their algorithm is actually an optimal
CAC. The key property needed for their algorithm to work is given as ConjectureAbelow.
For our purpose, we rephrase their conjecture in terms of cosets of the subgroup generated

( a _ { i } , b _ { i } , c _ { i } ) \in A _ { i } \times B _ { i } \times C _ { i }
a _ { i } + b _ { i } + c _ { i } = 0 \quad { \mathrm { i n ~ } } \mathbb { F } _ { p } .
